Question eight

Implement the suggestion about displaying a rotating cube in the program. Add a button that, when the cube is loaded, can update the locations of the cube vertices by computing them with a new value of t, the amount to rotate. To make the animation look smooth, try changing t by .05 radians per button click.

class RotatingCube

A class for displaying a rotating cube using Tkinter.

Variables:

  • master (tk.Tk) – The main Tkinter window.

  • width (int) – Width of the canvas.

  • height (int) – Height of the canvas.

  • t (float) – Current rotation angle.

  • cube_size (int) – Size of the cube.

  • vertices (list) – List of cube vertices.

  • canvas (tk.Canvas) – Tkinter canvas for drawing the cube.

  • update_button (tk.Button) – Tkinter button for updating the rotation.

__init__(master)

Initialize the RotatingCube object.

Parameters:

master (tk.Tk) – The main Tkinter window.

calculate_cube_vertices()

Calculate the vertices of the cube based on the current rotation angle.

Returns:

List of cube vertices.

draw_cube()

Draw the cube on the canvas.

Returns:

None

update_rotation()

Update the rotation angle and redraw the cube with smooth transitions.

Returns:

None

draw_polygon(face, color)

Draw a polygon on the canvas.

Parameters:

  • face (list) – List of vertices forming the polygon.

  • color (str) – Fill color of the polygon.

Returns:

None

main()

Main function to demonstrate the RotatingCube class.

Constants:

  • width (int): Width of the canvas (400).

  • height (int): Height of the canvas (400).

  • t (float): Initial rotation angle (0).

  • cube_size (int): Size of the cube (100).

Usage:

  • Create an instance of RotatingCube.

  • Draw the rotating cube on the canvas.

  • Use the button to update the rotation.

Example usage:

if __name__ == "__main__":
    root = tk.Tk()
    rotating_cube = RotatingCube(root)
    root.mainloop()
